clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Investigate Benefits of Weight Loss in Young Adults and Adolescents
clinical_study.official_title: Study to Investigate Benefits of Weight Loss in Yound Adults and Adolescents

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the changes in subcutaneous adipocyte size, number and gene expression after weight loss and to assess whether those changes contribute to decreases in ectopic fat accumulation and insulin resistance in women between ages of 16-32.

detailed_description.textblock: There are no studies in young women that have prospectively studied changes in fat cell size, gene expression and insulin sensitivity during the transition from overweight/obese to normal weight. Our preliminary data suggest that the presence of ectopic fat accumulation and insulin resistance in obese children could be considered an "early phase" in the development of T2DM. We hypothesize that a 10% weight loss will restore/improve insulin sensitivity. Furthermore, we speculate that the decrease in subcutaneous fat mass after weight loss is due to a decrease in mean adipocyte cell size, but not cell number.

primary_outcome.measure: Abdominal fat re-distribution with weight loss
primary_outcome.description: To assess in young women, the effects of weight loss on abdominal fat distribution.

secondary_outcome.measure: Adipocyte cell size distrubtion and gene expression
secondary_outcome.description: With 10% weight loss, assess changes in cell size distribution and gene expression of adipocytes from the subcutaneous adipose depot.

intervention.description: Patients will meet weekly with a registered dietician.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women ages 16-32
Exclusion Criteria:
- They will not be on any medications that are known to alter glucose or insulin metabolism, such as oral steroids, or certain psychiatric medications, such as Xeleca, Lithium and Paxil. Patients on diuretics will be excluded.

patient_data.ipd_description: IPD will not be shared with other researchers. Only group data that is used in data analysis for manuscripts will be shared and that is de-identified.
